newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Southeast power rises as thermometer dips.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Southeast power rises as thermometer dips.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. were driven higher again Tuesday by cold weather and the resulting shortage of supply and strong natural gas prices, sources said.
Firm, peak power prices in the northern part of the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) territory for Wednesday were sharply higher again after gaining about $8.00 Monday.
Traders said most deals were done around $31.00, as compared with the $21.00-23.00 trading range seen on Monday.
January/February TVA prices were talked in the $26.00-27.00 area.
Firm, off-peak electricity in northern TVA was notionally assessed at $15.00-17.00.
At the Georgia/Florida border, prices for firm, peak electricity in 16 hour blocks for Wednesday delivery were widely discussed in the $28.00-32.00 range, as compared with Monday's mid-$20s.
"Prices are pretty much converging everywhere in the Midwest and Southeast," one market source said.
Firm, off-peak power for Wednesday at the Ga./Fla. border was still notionally assessed at $15.50-16.00.

In Florida, where most daytime highs are in the 70s Fahrenheit and lows are in the 50s, peak power prices on a 16-hour schedule for Wednesday were discussed in the $34.00-36.00 range, as compared with the $23.00-25.00 area seen on Monday.
Temperatures in the region are expected to dip to about 10-20 degrees Fahrenheit below-normal Wednesday through Saturday.
Separately, Southern Co's 822 megawatt (MW) Farley 2 nuclear unit in Alabama, shut this weekend, is expected to restart Tuesday evening.
Entergy's 858 MW Arkansas 2 nuclear unit returned to the grid Tuesday.
Like power prices, natural gas spot values on the Gulf Coast rose by about 40 cents today into the low-$4.40s per million British thermal units.
